Boris Johnson ceasing to be prime minister of the UK before the 18th of September seems implausible. While there is a current uproar about the UK's role in the situation in Afghanistan, it does not appear to be targeted directly at Boris beyond the fact that he was on holiday during the events and did not recall parliament before the fall of Kabul. Dominic Raab has taken at least as much flack. Boris can, at the very least, extend his stay in number 10 with his cabinet reshuffle that will give the impression of doing something.
The current crisis in Afghanistan aside, Boris' ratings have taken a big dip but he still remains preferred to Keir Starmer as PM by the British public. Likewise, the conservatives are still ahead in the Westminster voting intention polls. With no conservative MP likely to be able to brand themselves as a better election winner than Boris, it seems extremely unlikely that Boris will cease to be PM in the near future.

Conservative MPs laying directly into Johnson over his handling of Afghanistan during emergency Parliamentary recall without a murmur of objection from their own party benches. Is this the watershed moment we've all known would come sooner or later?  Probably not, but the wheels are turning & disgraced PMs have gone within weeks before.

Recalibrating forecast given recent news about Dominic Cumming's (aka Michael Gove's) willingness to spill inside information to the press and various Parliamentary Select Committees.  Allegations begin again today, with headlines "let the bodies pile up in their thousands" representing this week's opening salvos [1].  It seems likely this is only going to get worse for the PM who is falling foul of the most Tory of Tory behaviours: inside dealing, corruption and self serving greed. Tory Leaders of history have found this to be their kryptonite, but today's world is different and today's UK populace seem strangely willing to accept such things in favour of something that Boris brings them in return (whatever that is...not sure anyone knows now that Brexit is done). To see the headline appear in the Mail, however [2]?  That feels like something different and shows that today's revelations are not being buffered by the traditionally Tory friendly broadsheet outlets.  The fact that all this is coming out in the weeks before the May elections is not, I believe, any form of coincidence.  The question therefore is why?  Why would a normally Tory and Johnson friendly paper pile in on such headlines and turn on "their man" in such a way?  We'll come back to that in a second. With Scottish elections likely to represent a drumming for Johnson's premiership as well, I wonder if my earlier premise about party insiders looking for "an opportune moment to throw him off the White Cliffs" now that Brexit is done might still hold some water. If there was a moment for a leadership crisis to be punted: a scandal ridden premiership that has just been given a whipping in local elections and looks like it might oversee the break up of the union might be just the moment such malign entities within the Tory Party would be looking for. As stated in my earlier rationale (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1211213) the ideal moment for the Tory party to commit to "BJexit" would seem to be later on in the term and closer to the next election (2022 or early 2023) when they can blame the losses and disasters of Brexit at his door before entering a "clean" candidate into the next election cycle. But the fact remains that the ice under Boris' feet is still wafer thin with very little room for manoeuvre or options to keep everyone happy.  If the ERG and Brexit hardliners in the various right wing UK media outlets (of which the Mail is definitely one) are feeling that their Clown Prince is caving (despite the press briefings and bombastic pronouncements) to EU and US pressure on NI protocols etc. [3] then these revelations suddenly take on a whole new meaning and a whole new projection for BJs future. This could also just as easily be the moment Gove (possibly in collaboration with his old partner in crime Cummings) has smelt sufficient blood in the water to make his vengeful move with support from his his wife's tabloid [4]. This is what happens to populist "finite game" players who lack the foresight, cognitive capacity and basic interest to play the "long, infinite" game and make policy on long standing, deeply held "principles" rather than flop around in a desperate effort to hold onto power.  You get yourself boxed into a corner with few good ways out.  Boris' history speaks of a man who doesn't like admitting any form of failure and never wants to face up to the hard choices of a "no win" scenario.  But like it or not, it seems that a no win scenario has caught up with him and those around him may now be smelling blood. Its a really hard one to forecast, particularly if you base all or most your forecasting evidence on what's in the media and the papers (which have been bailing furiously to keep Johnson afloat over the last 9 months).  I remain convicted that, for this question, its a mistake to not also take a good look at the ice beneath Johnson's feet and the heavily constrained environment in which he's currently flip flopping along [5]. The key part of this question is the date and the timing.  I do not see Johnson leading the Tories into the next election.  But can the momentum, outrage and pressure build in time to see Johnson's cork finally blow before this parliament's summer recess? If the May elections don't go as badly for Johnson as some current predictions suggest (both North and South of the Scottish border) then I think he's safe and forecast probability goes back down to near 0.  But if things go badly...we should all be listening very carefully for the sound of knives being sharpened (and Gove's back teeth chattering in glee). I'm all over the shop with this one. Reading between the lines and behind the rhetoric of Andrew Bailey's statement's [1 and 2] its hard not to get a sense of impotent panic in the BoE's (non-political?!) position on London's financial services, access to the EU derivative market and the time limited equivalency allowance. Sidebar: Andrew Bailey [3] was a very public supporter of Brexit [4], which I'm sure had absolutely no impact on his ascension to the position of Gov of the BoE in March 2020 after the tenure of the highly competent, highly capable (and quietly appalled [5]) Mark Carney. For all the noise and foot stamping going on, there doesn't seem to be many credible avenues for the BoE to "resist" the changes that the EU have been wanting to make for the last decade or more [6 and 7] but couldn't get their proposals past...the EU Court of Justice (we Brits do love a decent dose of irony in our daily diet). Now, thanks to Boris' Brexit, the EU have been granted the golden opportunity to reclaim huge amounts of London's financial power and derivative advantage that they were always looking for but could never achieve whilst the UK was an EU member state.  And it was the UK who voluntarily gave it to them ("will of the people", "Brexit means Brexit" etc. etc.). Is this relevant to this question?   Well, an €83.5tn slice of a €681tn market is not an amount to be sniffed at!  But given that the current EU granted equivalency deadline expires in June 2022 (and given BJ's propensity to leaving complex and high impact negotiations on key parts of the UK economy to the last second) it's hard to see a DIRECT route to this additional "Brexit dividend" unseating the Clown Prince within this question's 2021 timeframe. That said, once London's financial sector gives up on pressuring the now impotent BoE and the political appointee at its head to save their incomes, who might they point their very well funded (and traditionally Tory Party donating) ire towards next?  And how might they start expressing that ire towards a Government and a Party that has seriously undermined their bottom line with their flagging Brexit white elephant? As before, May 2021 feels like the next date to keep a keen eye on for this question.  If the city decides that the current short term focused, populism driven, incompetently managed and increasingly desperate UK government are an unresolvable blocker to their financial survival they may start exercising their considerable clout to asymmetrically topple the Clown Cart. Within 2021's timeframe (and remembering that negotiations for such a complex issue will take time and effort to conclude before the June 2022 equivalency expiry) May's Scottish Election results (predicted to be a damning reflection of BJ's "Union" leadership) might be the opportunity they choose to kick the stool out from under him (probably via behind the scenes pressure on the Party that backs him and relies so heavily on their continued patronage). Whilst short term pandemic and vaccination headlines dominate above the waterline of UK public consciousness (and seem to drive much of the probability forecasting here) the ice below the surface that's holding BJ and his Government up appears wafer thin and with fewer and fewer traditional Tory Party foundations holding it together. Its also critically important to remember that BJ is not Trump, and whilst BJ's approval ratings are stabilising in the near term absolutely no one in the UK will be storming the Houses of Parliament with St George flags and MUKGA hats if Johnson were to be unceremoniously booted from Downing Street tomorrow (Pro Brexit marches in 2019 only ever hit a few thousand [8] whereas anti-Brexit protests in 2019 reached several hundred thousand to +1million [9]). The sudden and unannounced departure of a failing (panicking) populist leader can happen in a second with the right stimulus and these are, to use the popular trope, "unprecedented times".  The trick for this question is identifying WHAT stimulus event(s) will cause their power base to shatter, and WHEN it/they might come. And down again with reporting that Hancock feels sufficiently Kevlar clad to use a BBC interview to justify his actions despite the Court ruling that his failure to publicise his dodgy contract awards broke the law. Dropping by a substantial 5% less for Hancock’s brazen “fake newsing” of the UK Justice system but more the statement from Kier Starmer that he won’t be calling for Hancock’s head because “thats not what the public want to see right now”.  This rather astounding capitulation from the opposition seems to indicate that Starmer is in no rush to chase down easy prey and is instead content to play a longer game (pushing any chance of such scandals feeding back on the PM further out of this question’s time frame). If his political calculus regarding the public mood is right then it seems the UK public is unlikely to rise up in fury at the waste of public funds on Tory friendlies.  Ergo, no willing or induced departure due to public furore any time soon. If his political calculus is wrong then this is a missed opportunity to bloody the Government’s nose with a topic that may be more raw in the public’s mind than his strategists believe (those with enough curiosity to find out about it: UK print media worked overtime to focus attention away and onto the shiny thing of “Harry and Megan” over the weekend).  Polling will show the impact of this scandal in subsequent months (on both the Governments behaviour and the Labour leaders willingness to let this one go)). The skipped opportunity to make a big noise about corruption in Government spending (a long standing sticky wicket for Tory Governments) may be Labour deliberately wanting to keep their powder dry in preparation for a bigger corruption scandal they know / believe may be coming down the road, or it may some other “politically strategic” play (e.g. in their calculations, the longer Boris is in charge the better their chances are in 2024: don’t give the Conservatives gift wrapped justifications to bounce him for someone more competent who’ll be harder to fight in the next election). Whichever reason is true, the opposition to BJ don’t seem to be in any hurry or working particularly hard to unseat him through public anger with these sort of opportunities.  Which means the Tory Party are going to have to do it themselves and on their timeline (unless Boris hears the knives being sharpened and jumps before the push comes: seemingly less likely this side of the questions closure).  So, for now, the May Scottish elections remain the only major event to watch and recalculate from for this question, and whatever the results with this it seems much more likely than not that Boris will ride out the questions time frame with his refusal to grant Scotland an IndyRef 2 and hope it all goes away (always a short term thinker that one). After reading some of the comments below from people who live in the UK, it seems less likely that Boris Johnson will cease to be prime minister of the UK before the next prime minister election.

There is no chance of him being voted out by the electorate as there is no election planned and his parliamentary majority protects him from a vote of no confidence. Unless, of course his party really do turn against him. This is unlikely as they have been very tolerant of his more, er, undisciplined behaviour in the past. So what is left is he dies or resigns. Taking the latter first, I can’t see him resigning at all let alone resigning in the next 8 months. He wants the job so much he would keep doing it until the bitter end even in the most dire circumstances. So that leaves the question if he will die in office. Update 1/20: I'm sticking with the 10% forecast, for reasons pulling in both directions. I love the roll-up by @TJA on resignations from conservative leaders, which I hadn't considered in calculating my base rate (that is, that conservative leader resignation is quite common, but under certain circumstances), and this insight tugs my forecast down (bc Johnson is within 4 years without an intervening election) . But negative press on Brexit fallout, Johnson's failure to close borders for COVID, and tarnishing UK's moral leadership by failing to sanction China for persecuting the Uighurs tugs the forecast in the other direction. So I stay at 10.  12/4: There are, from what I understand, three exit paths for Johnson prior to 18 Sept 2021: personal choice to step down; a vote of no confidence; a passing motion for an out-of-cycle general election. On personal choice, it is rumored that he could have lingering health issues that might encourage a lower-stress job: https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/downing-street-boris-johnson-quit-prime-minister-coronavirus-health-a9687206.html. On a vote of no confidence: in modern history, there have only been two successful in the last hundred years; one in 1979 and before that in 1924 (and two unsuccessful in 1993 and 2019) giving a base rate of roughly .16% in any given month for a no confidence vote to be cast. Finally, the potential for an out-of-cycle election being called for is dampened by having a majority in parliament, but increased by potential unfavorable Brexit terms/trade deal. Because of factors 1 (health) and 3 (Brexit), I'll up my negligible base rate to 10 percent.

The Conservative Party regularly deposes its leaders, but the circumstances under which it does so are instructive in calculating the chances of Boris Johnson no longer being Prime Minster by 18th September 2021. Most recent previous leaders, time served, and reasons for departure:
- Theresa May: resigned 2 years and 11 months after becoming leader. Internal Conservative pressure following failure to gain House of Commons approval for Brexit deal.
- David Cameron: resigned 6 years after becoming Prime Minister after leading losing Remain campaign in EU referendum.
- Michael Howard: resigned less than 2 years after becoming leader. Lost 2005 General Election.
- Iain Duncan Smith: resigned just over 2 years after becoming leader. Lost vote of confidence. 
- William Hague: resigned 4 years after becoming leader. Lost 2001 General Election. 
- John Major: resigned after almost 7 years as PM after losing 1997 General Election
- Margaret Thatcher: resigned after 11 years as PM after coming close to losing leadership election Only one Conservative leader of the last six has been ousted after less than 4 years without an intervening election. Boris Johnson won a comfortable majority at the 2019 General Election and his approval ratings have hovered between 35-45% approval since summer 2020, mirroring the Conservative Party's vote at the last election. https://yougov.co.uk/topics/politics/trackers/boris-johnson-approval-rating. While a change in leadership cannot be discounted before the next General Election in 2024, I anticipate no challenge will arise before September 2021. The most likely reason for Johnson's departure is perhaps health-related, although media appearances and reports from insiders suggest he has recovered well from his bad dose of Covid-19 in April 2020.

As others have noted, there are four ways Mr Johnson could cease to be PM: 1) Death
2) He is removed as leader of the Conservative Party
3) He loses a general election
4) He resigns His chance of dying, according to actuarial death tables, is roughly 0.7% for ten months. I'll bump that down to 0.5% because I can't be bothered to look up the tables myself. What am I, a library? He'll have better medical care than most, which may take down his chance of death, but there's always the chance someone will Spencer Perceval him, so I'm sticking with 0.5% With regard to his removal from the Conservative Party, many MPs are frustrated with his approach to the Coronavirus, but these concerns will abate once the UK's vaccination campaign continues to show its benefits. Even the opposition has been slow to criticise the broad points of government coronavirus policy, and public approval of lockdowns is high. Considering the poor coronavirus response, the Conservative Party is doing well in the polls, so Tory MPs will not be wary in this regard. The Coronavirus will continue to be the main issue in the news until September, so short of another major national emergency, I can't see the polls changing so drastically that Johnson is ousted. What's more, Johnson's ousting will plunge the party back into anarchy, as there is no obvious successor, nor even any clear candidates. In short, no group within the Party will be pushing for Johnson's resignation. Therefore, I put the chance of Johnson being ousted at about 0.5% The Conservatives have nothing to gain and everything to lose by calling a general election, so they will not do so, certainly not before September, when holding elections will still be logistically difficult given the after-effects of the coronavirus pandemic. Therefore, I put the chance of Johnson losing a general election as less than 0.1%. Johnson might resign. He is not known for giving up the limelight voluntarily, however, and he does not have an anointed successor in place, as resigning PMs often do. I think the only plausible reason he would resign is for health reasons. There have been rumours that he is suffering from long Covid, which is possible. There is always the outside chance that he is diagnosed with some other disease which forces him to retire as well. Nonetheless, Johnson has shown no indication that he wants to resign, and his job will only get easier as the pandemic fades. Further, it will be logistically difficult, even if Johnson does want to resign, for the Conservatives to run a proper leadership election, so unless Boris is literally incapable of working, I expect he will stay on as a lame duck. I put the chance of Boris resigning before September at about 3% This leaves me with a percentage chance of 4%

In talking with @Okanaganopolis I've just talked myself into a rise!  Rationale below, please feel free to challenge and counter-argue. ---------- Many seem to be basing their forecasts of BJ's continuing premiership in 9 months time on today's headlines. I think this is a mistake: they should be looking at the conditions that are GOING to be in place over the next 6 - 9 months time and focusing their view of BJ's fate in that future space. Here are the conditions (forecasted as I see them) that will manifest over the next 9 months: -Red tape and delays at UK trade points will start to manifest as stockpiles run dry, HMRCs "light touch" approach runs out and issues with new systems persist
-Louder criticisms of BJs deal will be heard from industry and trade groups (already heard from fishing groups but currently shouted down in the "get it done" euphoria) as benefits of the deal fail to materialise
-EU will play hard ball with UK negotiators on services provisions (notably absent from BJ's deal and 80% of the UK economic trade value: much more a priority for the UK than the EU) causing voices in the services industry, financial sector and London to be increasingly raised in anger at the lack of progress and opportunity since the Christmas Eve trade deal
-The UK will likely enter a nasty recession: a combination of COVID impacts and Brexit (although likely spun hard to blaming COVID by the UK gov and supportive media outlets)
-UK vaccine roll out programme will be delayed, resulting in further economic and societal impacts and increased criticism of UK Gov's handling of COVID 19
-UK COVID 19 deaths will pass 100,000 early in 2021: a horrendous benchmark that will draw likely comparisons between BJ and Trumps mismanagement of COVID 19 in the US
-People will start directly feeling the effects of Brexit (trade, travel, holidays, weakened pound increasing costs etc.) and will find them harder and harder to ignore / accept now that the finite game of "getting Brexit done" has played itself out
-Scottish Parliamentary Elections taking place 6th May 2021 currently promise a drumming for the Tories as a non-official referendum on independence from the UK and a repudiation of BJ's Brexit (certain to be used by the SNP as a lever for increased support to another independence referendum - https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-9103629/Nicola-Sturgeon-urges-EU-light-says-Scotland-soon.html). Irrespective of whether a referendum takes place or not BJ will be labelled as the harbinger of Scottish independence and the break up of the Union. I've worked hard to not allow pessimism to infect this analysis overmuch: these all seem credible features of the newly minted 2021 (whether we like to admit them or not). Now, its important to also see this through BJs eyes (not our own). BJ will KNOW that much of this is coming. He'll have the inside leg on future projections from Government briefings and will know what the future holds for him. So will his close ministers and senior Tory party members. BJ is (thankfully from a forecasting perspective) a predictably selfish and self-oriented character. When looking at the incoming scenarios of 2021 (and what he likely knows about them) its easy to build an argument for why he might want to resign or otherwise depart under a carefully curated justification ("Long COVID health concerns" is my bet) rather than stay. Then, look at what may be in play to make him want to stay in power: -Money?  There are reports he's been privately complaining that the PM job doesn't pay as much as his previous roles as journalist, columnist and after dinner speaker (https://inews.co.uk/news/politics/boris-johnson-miserable-upset-cant-afford-nanny-salary-654102). -His legacy? The longer he stays the more tarnished his legacy becomes. BJ will be looking (as he has in previous roles) to tap out at the moment of his popular zenith and before the implications of his actions become a harder to spin reality. This moment is potentially coming up with the beginning of the vaccine roll out programme Q1/2 2021. Everything after that moment seems to be downhill, so I believe the legacy argument actually strengthens the reasoning for his departure before Q3 2021 rather than refutes it. -His agenda? BJ is a what we call a "finite game player" (see James P Carse: Finite and Infinite Games). He's a chequers man rather than a chess master. His historical behaviour indicates a strong preference for short term goals and quick win soundbites (not long vision and strategy). His agenda was to take power and become PM (see his "two sides" telegraph articles for and against Brexit as an example of his cynical approach to this goal via championing Brexit: https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/16/secret-boris-johnson-column-favoured-uk-remaining-in-eu). In terms of his own agenda: he's achieved that now, and the longer he stays the more of a poison pill that role becomes (for him personally). In terms of the Tory Party, the more BJ and his cabinet bungle the management of this complex, congested, cluttered, contested, connected (disconnected?) and constrained post EU environment the UK finds itself in the more BJ is a threat to their agenda (of staying in power) by elevating the competence of Kier Starmer over "their man in No.10". The longer they leave it, the more bungles are possible (likely?) and the more reputational damage needs to be repaired before May 2024's general election. I also think its a mistake to limit the view of "ejection scenarios" to a pre 2024 general election. This is certainly phenomenally unlikely given the Tory majority in parliament and no good reason (currently) to put their control on the line. Likewise, BJs ejection in a very public vote of no confidence is (currently) unlikely - the Tories carry out their leadership assassinations behind closed doors and out of the line of sight of the public (see Theresa May's demise: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/05/16/brexit-latest-news-theresa-may-set-showdown-meeting-senior-tories/) to maintain an outward perception of unity. I would offer that, from the Tory Party's perspective, BJ has now served his purpose. He has delivered them four years in government and rid them of the (internally and externally) divisive issue of Brexit. What more use do they have for him that would make them content to tolerate his continued incompetence? From the cannibalistic Tory party's viewpoint BJ will now be a useful scapegoat to blame for any painful realities Brexit visits on the UK in 2021 and any growth in furore over continued COVID mismanagement. The closer they cut this "scapegoating" to an election year the more it's taint on the wider party will be present in the minds and memories of the UK electorate come May 2024. As such I believe the Tory Party will be planning for a "BJexit" between Q3 2022 and Q1 2023 leaving enough time to choose a suitable future candidate and curate his (her?) fresh face for the UK electorate before 2024's election. We should also remember that BJ has been playing this game for some time and is himself an opportunist and a political animal. We can safely assume he probably knows how fragile his position is and what may come next from within his party. He'll start hearing the knives being sharpened more and more loudly as the populist noise of Brexit subsides and reality bites. This also supports an argument for his voluntary departure at a "legacy friendly" moment: he'll want to jump (with a reputational parachute fitted) before his own party push him off Dover's white cliffs with all the incoming travails the UK faces tied to his ankles. As of right now BJ leaving office would be defined (not  unfairly but also not entirely correctly) as an unexpected "Black Swan" event. But Black Swans are only a surprise to those who don't know what conditions to look for that pre-empt their manifestation. BJ and the Tory party will never openly (and honestly) telegraph their intentions on this matter or this questions forecasted outcome, so relying on press releases and "the mood of the moment" are unreliable forecasting indicators at best. Conditions, however, don't lie (although they can be lied about).

Next General Election is set for 2024 and the British public has been fatigued by repeated elections and referenda over the last few years. If PM Johnson ceases to lead the country by 18 Sep 2021, it seems unlikely to be as a result of an election. What other possibilities exist then?
- Dismissal by the monarch: 0% chance; hasn't happened since William Lamb in 1834
- Loss of confidence from his own party: always a possibility, though many of his transgressions have been forgiven before, even throughout the pandemic and EU negotiations, when opportunities and "crises" have arisen
- Death: everyone dies, but Boris has already managed to get through a bout of COVID, so causes and likelihood are still a gamble for the 56-year old leader
- Resignation: Resignation possibilities are always present. Of 28 PMs that have served in the 20th-21st centuries, 8 have resigned (28.5%). Analysing reasons for resignations would lead to a different base rate, however, since among these were resignations due to ill health (Anthony Eden and Winston Churchill), loss of the general election (Gordon Brown), and stepping aside after extended leadership time (Tony Blair, and in the case of Thatcher eventual loss of confidence). The Conservative party might not withstand 3(!) back-to-back resignations, over Brexit-related issues (Cameron and May already did so), so this seems less likely to be the way forward by Sept 2021. Johnson has only been at the helm a relatively short time and is keen to take his one-issue Brexit agenda forward as long as he can. Personal issues or scandal would probably be the most likely cause of any upheaval and subsequent resignation in my estimation, (though that hasn't caused other populist leaders to step aside...)
I'm therefore starting off my estimate at 10% and will adjust.

BASE RATES
This question is the same as asking if Boris Johnson will be PM for 787 days ~ 2.16 years, or more. Outside view: of the last 10 PMs (not including Johnson), only one served less than 2.16y [1]: Alec Douglas-Home, at 0.99y. This suggests a base rate of 10% for this question. However, Douglas-Home is also the least recent of the 10 (1963); and Johnson has served ~1.33y already, so really we want the odds of a PM serving <2.16y *given that* they have served >1.33y. And in the sample of 10, these odds are 0%. So maybe we shade that 10% down a little, to 8% say. If we look at PMs after WW2 (a natural breakpoint I think) we get 13 PMs, and 1 that served >1.33y but less than 2.16y. That gives an alternative base rate of 1/13 ~ 7.7%, reassuringly close to 8%, so let's go with 8%. There's also the chance that Johnson dies. Actuarial death tables put the chances of a 56yo man over ~10 months at ~0.7%. There is of course the coronavirus going around, but Johnson has already had it; and when he had it, we saw that he has better medical care available to him than the average person. So I'm comfortable keeping his chance of dying at ~1%, making for a base rate of 9%. INTERNAL POLITICS
Now for the inside view. Johnson is leader of the Conservative Party, which holds a straight majority in the Commons by a margin of 38, and that's not even counting allied parties such as the DUP. The next elections are scheduled for 2024. So it seems very unlikely he will be forced out. That leaves the option that he steps down voluntarily. The two big reasons I see for stepping down are the coronavirus, and Brexit. CORONAVIRUS
The coronavirus seems to have had a real impact on Johnson's popularity [2]. At the beginning of 2020 Johnson's net approval (positive minus negative) was roughly in the interval [-5%,5%], which I gather is normal in the UK. Then there was a big positive jump (to about +20%) in late March that lasted through May. Then public opinion roughly returned to the status quo around -6% through early September. And then there was a big negative dip and sits around -20% now. How does this correlate with covid? Roughly speaking, in the positive period the UK had a big rise in daily covid cases and deaths. The status quo period saw daily cases stabilize at low values, and daily deaths plummet. Then the negative period was when daily cases and deaths rose massively. It's a bit weird that Johnson's approval went up as covid got worse in Mar-Apr, and even weirder that it didn't skyrocket in Jun-Aug when the UK got covid temporarily under control. Maybe the approval correlates with lockdown in a more understandable way? The following is all from [3]. They had serious lockdown from late March through mid-May. In June the restrictions were eased significantly, with some shops and schools reopening. In July and August things reopened further. But in mid-Sep gatherings of 6+ people were made illegal due to the rise in cases, and since then restrictions have increased. I don't get it. But, it seems reasonable that if covid continues to get worse, Johnson will be in real trouble. What's going to happen there? There are the vaccines, which may start deployment as soon as 7 Dec 2020 [4]. They're over 90% effective in trials, so let's roughly say there's an 80% chance they majorly helps with covid; 10% chance they help some but not as much as 90+% would suggest; and 10% chance they flop. In the first case I can't see Johnson stepping down by September for covid reasons. In the second case it seems like low odds, let's say 20% chance given that vaccines help mildly (so 2% total). In the third case I want to say 70% chance he steps down (so 7% total). When will we know which case happened? That will depend on speed of vaccine rollout. But even at 100k/day (I heard 1M/day was the goal at peak) we will have ~5M vaccinated by end of Feb 2021 (recall that it's 2 doses). This is going to be more than enough data for us to find out how the vaccines are doing. By the end of May 2021, assuming 500k/day, we'll have another 23M vaccinated. So by late June we'll definitely know. That leaves plenty of time for Johnson to step down by Sep 2021 if we end up in the bad case. So add 2%+7% to the base rate since the average PM does not deal with a pandemic, bringing us to 18% total. BREXIT

Looking at the last 20 prime ministers, a prime minister has ~50-50 odds of reaching 1514 days in office: At this time, Boris has spent 485 days in office, so he's "got" 1029 "expected" days remaining. Only 4 prime ministers have served 787 days or fewer (that would take us to 2021-Sep-18), giving him and outside view of 22%  (Bayesian update of an uninformative prior; Beta(5, 17) => E[X] = 5 / (5+17) = 22%, 95% CI: 8% - 42%). However, he's passed the 485 day mark, so let's work out the daily odds: 1 - (! - p)^787 = 0.22... => p ≈ 0.000327556... Chance in the remaining 302 days: 1 - (1 - 0.000327556..)^302 = 0.0942... = 9% outside view. He was a fairly popular prime minister, and won the most recent election most convincingly of any recent Conservative. A lot of folks like him and look past his flaws and failures. Now, let's look at the factors making him less stable:   1. Brexit. He'll get blamed if this goes badly. He campaigned for leave, it's his deal, and he's handling the prep.
  2. COVID-19. The UK hasn't fared well compared with other countries. Combined with Brexit, this has shaken the country, especially with the regular news about the various govt' failures (PPE, test & trace). Many may forgive him for these, especially on the Conservative side. They may write it off as "simply bad luck" and "outside his control". This might be doubly true if they strongly agree with the measures he has taken. The swing voters might be less easily convinced that it was all luck. I think each of these factors is worth a 2 - 4% bump. Call it 6%, giving an overall 15% chance of replacement by 2021-Sep-18. Data: ```

There are a few ways for Boris Johnson to cease to be prime minister.  1. Death - Boris Johnson is a 56 year old male, and by the Actuarial Life Table, there is about a 1% chance he dies in the next year [1]. 
2. Conservative leadership election - These seem to be called after a prime minister resigns but can be called if the party just wants to remove the current leader. [2]  [3] There have been 11 conservative leadership elections since 1965, which is about 1 every 5 years. This is the most likely way Johnson ceases to be prime minister. If the conservative party is sufficiently unhappy with his management of Coronavirus, Brexit, or the many other issues facing Johnson, he could face a challenge within his party. So much is up in the air here. It seems based on the previous leadership elections, they are called if a) the leader lost a general election by a large margin b) the leader has performed poorly in non-electoral fashions or c) the incumbent leader resigns. I doubt a) or c) occur for Boris Johnson, so I'll go a bit under the base rate of 20%. 
3. Loses a general election - Given that next prime minister general election is schedule for 2024 [4] this Johnson should not be removed by a vote of the populace. Unless Johnson calls for some sort of referendum vote like Cameron did (which I can't imagine) he should be safe on this front.  Let me know if I missed something, especially in the conservative leadership election party (#2). 
[1] https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
[2] https://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/blog/history-changes-prime-minister
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leadership_election#United_Kingdom
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_United_Kingdom_general_election

The last PM to retire for health reasons was Harold Wilson in 1976 after 2 years in office(1) which was due to very serious health issues. The average amount of time a government lasts is either 3.7 or 4.1 years (2) (the current government having been in place since December, so 9 months). Johnson has been PM since July of last year. The fixed term parliament act is still currently in effect so there will not be a election until 2024 unless Parliament dissolves before then. Johnson is 56, so has a less than 1% chance of death in the next year. The current majority in the Commons is 80, which is a large majority, and many of his MPs owe their seats to him.
